body_html:
Am I not installing nsync right: is make enough for installation?

You're doing a bazel build; there should be no need to invoke make on nsync.
If you invoke bazel in the tensorflow tree, bazel will fetch and build the version of the nsync package
associated with the version of the tensorflow package that you've downloaded.

The problem is that you're using a version of tensorflow that's using an older version of nsync.
As I said earlier, this is clear from the line number in the error message you quote.
Notice the "397" in the error message: that line number can only have been
produced by an erlier version of nsync.

As I recommended earlier, use the head version of tensorflow.
If you instead wish to use v1.4.0-rc1, you must tell bazel to
use the most recent version of nsync. To do that,
in tensorflow's workspace.bzl (at line 426 in v1.4.0-rc1)
modify the stanza that fetches nsync to read as follows:

native.http_archive(
  name = "nsync",
  urls = [
      "https://mirror.bazel.build/github.com/google/nsync/archive/839fcc53ff9be58218ed55397deb3f8376a1444e.tar.gz",
      # "https://github.com/google/nsync/archive/839fcc53ff9be58218ed55397deb3f8376a1444e.tar.gz",
  ],
  sha256 = "124d105edb0313ef2d7f5bb86ec94d9f8de95479e55641c4254ffa8f795e9b37",
  strip_prefix = "nsync-839fcc53ff9be58218ed55397deb3f8376a1444e",

)

The warning you quote about the cc_header_only_library rule is harmless.
It represents an unfortunate interaction between tensorflow and bazel.
It occurs on all platforms, and is not peculiar to the Mac.
TensorFlow attempts to define a rule that exports just the headers from a library,
but bazel makes it difficult to construct the include path for such a
custom rule, based on its dependencies.
It is unclear how this will be resolved as bazel evolves, but for the moment
things work, with a warning message.
body_text:
Am I not installing nsync right: is make enough for installation?

You're doing a bazel build; there should be no need to invoke make on nsync.
If you invoke bazel in the tensorflow tree, bazel will fetch and build the version of the nsync package
associated with the version of the tensorflow package that you've downloaded.
The problem is that you're using a version of tensorflow that's using an older version of nsync.
As I said earlier, this is clear from the line number in the error message you quote.
Notice the "397" in the error message: that line number can only have been
produced by an erlier version of nsync.
As I recommended earlier, use the head version of tensorflow.
If you instead wish to use  v1.4.0-rc1, you must tell bazel to
use the most recent version of nsync.  To do that,
in tensorflow's workspace.bzl (at line 426 in v1.4.0-rc1)
modify the stanza that fetches nsync to read as follows:

  urls = [

      # "https://github.com/google/nsync/archive/839fcc53ff9be58218ed55397deb3f8376a1444e.tar.gz",
  ],
  sha256 = "124d105edb0313ef2d7f5bb86ec94d9f8de95479e55641c4254ffa8f795e9b37",
  strip_prefix = "nsync-839fcc53ff9be58218ed55397deb3f8376a1444e",

)

It represents an unfortunate interaction between tensorflow and bazel.
It occurs on all platforms, and is not peculiar to the Mac.

body:
> Am I not installing nsync right: is make enough for installation?

You're doing a bazel build; there should be no need to invoke make on nsync.
If you invoke bazel in the tensorflow tree, bazel will fetch and build the version of the nsync package
associated with the version of the tensorflow package that you've downloaded.

The problem is that you're using a version of tensorflow that's using an older version of nsync.
As I said earlier, this is clear from the line number in the error message you quote.
Notice the "397" in the error message: that line number can only have been 
produced by an erlier version of nsync.

As I recommended earlier, use the head version of tensorflow.
If you instead wish to use  v1.4.0-rc1, you must tell bazel to
use the most recent version of nsync.  To do that,
in tensorflow's workspace.bzl (at line 426 in v1.4.0-rc1)
modify the stanza that fetches nsync to read as follows:

    native.http_archive(
      name = "nsync",
      urls = [
          "https://mirror.bazel.build/github.com/google/nsync/archive/839fcc53ff9be58218ed55397deb3f8376a1444e.tar.gz",
          # "https://github.com/google/nsync/archive/839fcc53ff9be58218ed55397deb3f8376a1444e.tar.gz",
      ],
      sha256 = "124d105edb0313ef2d7f5bb86ec94d9f8de95479e55641c4254ffa8f795e9b37",
      strip_prefix = "nsync-839fcc53ff9be58218ed55397deb3f8376a1444e",
  )


----

The warning you quote about the cc_header_only_library rule is harmless.
It represents an unfortunate interaction between tensorflow and bazel.
It occurs on all platforms, and is not peculiar to the Mac.  
TensorFlow attempts to define a rule that exports just the headers from a library, 
but bazel makes it difficult to construct the include path for such a 
custom rule, based on its dependencies.
It is unclear how this will be resolved as bazel evolves, but for the moment
things work, with a warning message.
